1. promo/models.py

python
from django.db import models

class Submitter(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    email = models.EmailField(unique=True)
    contact_number = models.CharField(max_length=15)
    address = models.TextField()
    promo_code = models.CharField(max_length=20, unique=True)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} - {self.promo_code}"

2. promo/forms.py

python
from django import forms
from .models import Submitter

class SubmitterForm(forms.ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = Submitter
        fields = ['name', 'email', 'contact_number', 'address']

3. promo/views.py

python
import random, string
from django.core.mail import send_mail
from django.shortcuts import render
from .forms import SubmitterForm
from .models import Submitter
from django.http import JsonResponse

def generate_promo_code():
    return 'PROMO15-' + ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits, k=6))

def home(request):
    form = SubmitterForm()
    return render(request, 'promo/home.html', {'form': form})

def submit_form(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        form = SubmitterForm(request.POST)
        if form.is_valid():
            promo_code = generate_promo_code()
            submitter = form.save(commit=False)
            submitter.promo_code = promo_code
            submitter.save()

            # Send email
            send_mail(
                subject='Your Promo Code',
                message=f"Thanks for signing up! Your 15% promo code is: {promo_code}",
                from_email='no-reply@example.com',
                recipient_list=[submitter.email],
                fail_silently=False,
            )
            return JsonResponse({'status': 'success', 'promo_code': promo_code})
        else:
            return JsonResponse({'status': 'error', 'errors': form.errors})

4. promo/urls.py

python
from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('', views.home, name='home'),
    path('submit/', views.submit_form, name='submit_form'),
]

6. promo/templates/promo/home.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>QR Promo</title>
    <script src="https://unpkg.com/html5-qrcode"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Scan QR Code</h1>
    <div id="qr-reader" style="width:300px;"></div>
    
    <div id="form-container" style="display:none;">
        <h2>Fill Your Details</h2>
        <form id="submit-form">
            {% csrf_token %}
            {{ form.as_p }}
            <button type="submit">Submit</button>
        </form>
    </div>

    <div id="success-message" style="display:none;"></div>

    <script>
        function onScanSuccess(decodedText) {
            document.getElementById('qr-reader').style.display = 'none';
            document.getElementById('form-container').style.display = 'block';
        }

        let qrScanner = new Html5QrcodeScanner("qr-reader", { fps: 10, qrbox: 250 });
        qrScanner.render(onScanSuccess);

        document.getElementById('submit-form').addEventListener('submit', function(e) {
            e.preventDefault();
            let formData = new FormData(this);
            fetch("{% url 'submit_form' %}", {
                method: 'POST',
                headers: {
                    'X-CSRFToken': formData.get('csrfmiddlewaretoken'),
                },
                body: formData
            }).then(response => response.json())
              .then(data => {
                  if (data.status === 'success') {
                      document.getElementById('form-container').style.display = 'none';
                      document.getElementById('success-message').innerText =
                          "Success! Your promo code is: " + data.promo_code;
                      document.getElementById('success-message').style.display = 'block';
                  } else {
                      alert("Error: " + JSON.stringify(data.errors));
                  }
              });
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>

ChatGPT said:

To configure a no-reply email address in Django, you need to:

âœ… 1. Create or Use a No-Reply Email Address

Choose one of these:

  • Your domain provider (e.g., GoDaddy, Namecheap) â€” create no-reply@yourdomain.com.

  • Email hosting provider (like Gmail, Zoho, Outlook, Amazon SES, SendGrid, etc.).

âœ… 2. Django settings.py Email Configuration

Hereâ€™s how to configure popular providers. Replace values accordingly:

ðŸ”¹ Gmail SMTP (for testing only; not ideal for production)

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.gmail.com'
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'no-reply@yourdomain.com'
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your-app-password'  # Use an App Password, not your Gmail password
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'no-reply@yourdomain.com'

âœ… For Gmail, enable 2-Step Verification, then create an App Password for SMTP.

ðŸ”¹ SendGrid (Recommended for transactional email)

  1. Sign up at https://sendgrid.com/

  2. Create an API Key

  3. In settings.py:

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.sendgrid.net'
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'apikey'  # This is literally the word 'apikey'
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your_sendgrid_api_key'
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'no-reply@yourdomain.com'

ðŸ”¹ Amazon SES (for large-scale emails)

  1. Set up SES and verify the domain and email.

  2. Configure SMTP credentials.

  3. Add in settings.py:

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = 'email-smtp.us-east-1.amazonaws.com'  # region-specific
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'your_smtp_username'
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your_smtp_password'
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'no-reply@yourdomain.com'

ðŸ” Testing Email in Development

Instead of sending real emails during development, use:

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.console.EmailBackend'

It prints emails to the console.

You said:
how to get smtp user name and password>?
ChatGPT said:

To get the SMTP username and password, the process depends on your email provider. Below are step-by-step guides for the most common ones:

âœ… 1. Gmail / Google Workspace

ðŸ›‘ You must not use your Gmail password. Use an App Password instead.

ðŸ”¹ Steps:

  1. Go to Google Account Security.

  2. Enable 2-Step Verification (if not already).

  3. Go to App Passwords: https://myaccount.google.com/apppasswords

  4. Generate a new App Password (choose "Mail" and "Other" for custom name like "Django").

  5. It gives you a 16-character password â€” this is your SMTP password.

  6. SMTP username = your Gmail address (e.g., no-reply@yourdomain.com)

âœ… 2. SendGrid

ðŸ”¹ Steps:

  1. Go to SendGrid Dashboard.

  2. Navigate to Settings > API Keys.

  3. Click Create API Key.

  4. Choose Full Access or Restricted (for just sending emails).

  5. Save the generated key â€” this is your SMTP password.

  6. SMTP username = apikey (literally the word "apikey").

âœ… 3. Zoho Mail

ðŸ”¹ Steps:

  1. Log in to Zoho Mail Admin Console.

  2. Go to Mail Accounts > SMTP Settings.

  3. Username: your Zoho email (e.g., no-reply@yourdomain.com)

  4. Password: either your Zoho password or an App Password (recommended).

âœ… 4. Amazon SES (Simple Email Service)

ðŸ”¹ Steps:

  1. Go to AWS SES Console.

  2. Choose SMTP Settings from the left sidebar.

  3. Click Create SMTP Credentials.

  4. Set IAM username and click â€œCreateâ€.

  5. AWS gives you:

    • SMTP Username

    • SMTP Password (secure password â€” not your AWS account password)

âœ… 5. Custom Email Hosting (e.g., cPanel, Hostinger, etc.)

  • Login to your cPanel or dashboard.

  • Navigate to Email Accounts.

  • Find the no-reply@yourdomain.com account.

  • There youâ€™ll find SMTP credentials and outgoing mail server info.

Example: Using with Django

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.sendgrid.net'          # or smtp.gmail.com / email-smtp.us-east-1.amazonaws.com etc.
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'apikey'                # or your full email like no-reply@domain.com
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your-smtp-password-or-api-key'
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'no-reply@yourdomain.com'

3. views.py

python
from django.shortcuts import render, redirect
from .forms import PromoForm
from .models import PromoSubmission
from django.core.mail import send_mail
import random, string

def generate_promo_code():
    return 'PROMO15-' + ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits, k=6))

def home(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        form = PromoForm(request.POST)
        if form.is_valid():
            promo_code = generate_promo_code()
            instance = form.save(commit=False)
            instance.promo_code = promo_code
            instance.save()

            send_mail(
                subject='Your 15% Promo Code',
                message=f"Thank you for submitting your details. Your promo code is: {promo_code}",
                from_email='no-reply@yourdomain.com',
                recipient_list=[form.cleaned_data['email']],
                fail_silently=False,
            )
            return render(request, 'index.html', {'form': PromoForm(), 'success': True})
    else:
        form = PromoForm()
    return render(request, 'index.html', {'form': form})

You said:
the client should scan our qr code and how can we generate the qr code as well and add the data of qr code to add the details
ChatGPT said:

To implement a complete QR code scan system where:

  1. âœ… A QR code is generated with a unique URL (e.g., https://yourdomain.com/promo/?ref=abcd1234)

  2. âœ… A user scans it using their phone

  3. âœ… A form is displayed (Name, Email, Contact Number, Address)

  4. âœ… On submission:

    • A promo code is emailed

    • Data is stored in the DB

âœ… Step-by-Step Guide

1. ðŸ”§ Generate the QR Code in Django

Use the qrcode and Pillow libraries:

bash
pip install qrcode pillow

In views.py:

python
import qrcode
from django.http import HttpResponse
from io import BytesIO

def generate_qr(request):
    unique_code = "promo1234"  # Ideally dynamically generated
    url = f"https://yourdomain.com/promo/?ref={unique_code}"

    qr = qrcode.make(url)
    buffer = BytesIO()
    qr.save(buffer)
    buffer.seek(0)

    return HttpResponse(buffer.getvalue(), content_type="image/png")

In urls.py:

python
path('generate_qr/', views.generate_qr, name='generate_qr'),

Visiting /generate_qr/ will show a QR image that links to /promo/?ref=promo1234.

2. ðŸ“„ Create the Form View for /promo/

views.py:

python
from django.shortcuts import render, redirect
from .models import PromoSubmission
from .forms import PromoForm
from django.core.mail import send_mail
import uuid

def promo_form(request):
    ref_code = request.GET.get('ref', '')  # from QR code
    if request.method == 'POST':
        form = PromoForm(request.POST)
        if form.is_valid():
            submission = form.save(commit=False)
            submission.ref_code = ref_code
            submission.promo_code = f"PROMO-{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"
            submission.save()

            # Send email with promo code
            send_mail(
                subject='Your Promo Code!',
                message=f"Thank you! Your promo code is: {submission.promo_code} (15% off!)",
                from_email='no-reply@yourdomain.com',
                recipient_list=[submission.email],
            )
            return render(request, 'thank_you.html', {'promo_code': submission.promo_code})
    else:
        form = PromoForm()
    return render(request, 'promo_form.html', {'form': form})

3. ðŸ“¦ Model & Form

models.py:

python
from django.db import models

class PromoSubmission(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    email = models.EmailField()
    contact = models.CharField(max_length=15)
    address = models.TextField()
    promo_code = models.CharField(max_length=20)
    ref_code = models.CharField(max_length=50, blank=True)
    submitted_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

forms.py:

python
from django import forms
from .models import PromoSubmission

class PromoForm(forms.ModelForm):
    class Meta:
        model = PromoSubmission
        fields = ['name', 'email', 'contact', 'address']

âœ… Current Functionality Summary

  • A user visits a URL that may contain a ?ref=<code> query parameter.

    Update generate_qr view like:

    python
    def generate_qr(request):
    ref_code = uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]  # Generate unique referral code
    url = f"http://127.0.0.1:8000/promo/?ref={ref_code}"
    qr = qrcode.make(url)
    buffer = BytesIO()
    qr.save(buffer)
    buffer.seek(0)
    return HttpResponse(buffer.getvalue(), content_type='image/png')

    Optionally, you can log or store the generated ref_code to track referrals.

"/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.12/lib/python3.12/ssl.py", line 1319, in do_handshake self._sslobj.do_handshake() ssl.SSLCertVerificationError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self-signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:1000)
ChatGPT said:

This error means that Python's SSL module is trying to verify an HTTPS certificate, but it encountered a self-signed certificate that it doesn't trust. This usually occurs when:

  • You're using a corporate proxy, self-hosted SMTP server, or development certificate (e.g. with SendGrid or local testing).

  • Your system/Python doesn't have the right CA certificates installed or configured.

âœ… Common Fixes

1. For macOS: Install or Update CA Certificates

Run this in your terminal:

bash
/Applications/Python\ 3.12/Install\ Certificates.command

This script comes bundled with the official Python installer from python.org. It installs a proper set of root certificates using certifi.

2. Trust the Self-Signed Certificate (Advanced / Not Recommended for Production)

If you're working in development and must bypass SSL verification (e.g., for internal testing):

A. For Requests (like to SendGrid or a custom API):

python
import requests
response = requests.get('https://example.com', verify=False)

âš ï¸ This disables certificate verification â€” don't use it in production.

B. For Django Email (SMTP with self-signed cert):
Override EMAIL_USE_TLS and use an EMAIL_BACKEND that skips verification â€” or better, fix the cert chain on the mail server.

3. SendGrid Specific Fixes

If you're seeing this when sending email via SendGrid, ensure:

  • Your EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD is set to your SendGrid API key, not an actual password.

  • You are using:

    python
    EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.sendgrid.net'
EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'apikey'  # literally 'apikey'
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your_sendgrid_api_key'

SendGrid uses trusted certs, so if you're getting SSL errors with them, itâ€™s likely a local cert or network issue (like a MITM proxy or outdated certs).

ChatGPT said:

Sure â€” hereâ€™s a detailed explanation of how and why to correctly set up Gmail SMTP for sending emails in your Django app:

ðŸ§© SMTP Email Configuration in Django with Gmail

Django uses SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) to send emails. When using Gmail, your Django app must:

  1. Authenticate using a Gmail account

  2. Use a secure App Password (not your Gmail login password)

  3. Set the same email address for EMAIL_HOST_USER and DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL

ðŸ”§ Required Django Settings

In your settings.py, use the following:

python
EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.gmail.com'
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True

EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'yourgmail@gmail.com'         # Gmail address you're sending from
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your-app-password'       # 16-character password generated from Google
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'yourgmail@gmail.com'      # Must match EMAIL_HOST_USER

ðŸ›¡ Why You Need an App Password

Google does not allow less secure apps to send emails using just a username/password anymore. Instead:

âœ… You must generate an App Password if:

  • You have 2-Step Verification enabled (recommended)

  • You want a safe way for your app to send emails without exposing your Gmail login

ðŸ” Steps to get an App Password:

  1. Go to https://myaccount.google.com/apppasswords

  2. Select Mail as the app

  3. Select your device (or "Other" and type something like "Django App")

  4. Click Generate

  5. Youâ€™ll get a 16-character password like: abcd efgh ijkl mnop

Use that password as your EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD.

ðŸ” What Happens During Sending

When send_mail() or similar functions are called in Django:

  1. It connects to smtp.gmail.com on port 587

  2. Authenticates using EMAIL_HOST_USER and EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD

  3. Sends an email from DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL

  4. Gmail checks:

    • Does the sender match the authenticated account?

    • Is the App Password valid?

If any mismatch occurs, Gmail returns:

550: The from address does not match a verified sender identity.

ðŸ§ª Example Code in Views

python
from django.core.mail import send_mail

send_mail(
    subject='Welcome!',
    message='Thanks for signing up!',
    from_email='yourgmail@gmail.com',
    recipient_list=['someone@example.com'],
    fail_silently=False,
)

âœ… Summary: Best Practice

SettingValueWhy it's needed
EMAIL_HOST_USERyourgmail@gmail.comGmail SMTP login
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD16-char App PasswordSecure, approved by Google
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAILyourgmail@gmail.comMust match Gmail account

ChatGPT said:

Great follow-up â€” let me explain clearly what an "authenticated account" means, especially in the context of using SMTP for sending emails.

âœ… What Is an Authenticated Account?

An authenticated account is the email account whose credentials (username and password) you're using to log into the SMTP server to send mail.

For example, in Django settings:

python
EMAIL_HOST = 'smtp.gmail.com'
EMAIL_PORT = 587
EMAIL_USE_TLS = True

EMAIL_HOST_USER = 'yourgmail@gmail.com'         # ðŸ‘ˆ Authenticated account (your login email)
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = 'your-app-password'       # ðŸ‘ˆ App-specific password for login
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = 'yourgmail@gmail.com'      # ðŸ‘ˆ This must match or be an alias of EMAIL_HOST_USER

This means:

  • You are logging into Gmailâ€™s SMTP server as yourgmail@gmail.com

  • All emails sent are on behalf of that Gmail account

âš ï¸ Why Gmail (and most SMTP servers) Care

When you send an email, you're essentially telling Gmail:

"Hey Gmail, Iâ€™m logging in as yourgmail@gmail.com but I want the recipient to see it as coming from no-reply@yourdomain.com."

Gmail (and other providers) block this unless:

  • no-reply@yourdomain.com is a verified alias for the authenticated account, or

  • You're using a service that allows domain-level authorization (e.g., SendGrid, Amazon SES, Mailgun)

ðŸ” Key Rule

The DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL (the "From" email your users see) must be either:

  • The same as EMAIL_HOST_USER, or

  • A verified alias or authorized sender identity

âœ… Summary

SettingWhat It Represents
EMAIL_HOST_USERAuthenticated account (SMTP login)
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORDPassword for that account (or API key)
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAILFrom address shown to user â€” must be authorized

from .forms import PromoForm

def promo_form(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        form = PromoForm(request.POST)
        if form.is_valid():
            submission = form.save()

            # Compose promo code message
            promo_code = 'PROMO1234'  # Or generate dynamically
            subject = 'Your Promo Code ðŸŽ'
            message = f"Hi {submission.name},\n\nThank you for registering! Your promo code is: {promo_code}\n\nEnjoy!"
            recipient = submission.email

            # Send the email
            send_mail(
                subject,
                message,
                'no-reply@yourdomain.com',  # Must be verified in SendGrid
                [recipient],
                fail_silently=False  # Set to True to suppress errors
            )

            return redirect('success_page')  # Replace with your actual redirect
    else:
        form = PromoForm()

    return render(request, 'promo_form.html', {'form': form})

Sure â€” here's another approach: instead of using SendGrid's SMTP, you can use SendGridâ€™s Web API to send emails. This method is modern, often more reliable, and avoids SMTP-related issues.

âœ… Approach 2: Sending Emails with SendGrid Web API (Recommended)

ðŸ§© Step 1: Install SendGrid Python SDK

bash
pip install sendgrid

ðŸ” Step 2: Get Your SendGrid API Key

  1. Go to https://app.sendgrid.com/settings/api_keys

  2. Click â€œCreate API Keyâ€

  3. Give it a name (e.g., promo_api)

  4. Select Full Access or at least Mail Send permissions

  5. Copy and save the key (starts with SG.)

ðŸ›  Step 3: Django View to Send Email via API

python
import sendgrid
from sendgrid.helpers.mail import Mail
from django.conf import settings

def send_promocode_email(to_email, promo_code):
    message = Mail(
        from_email='promocode1595@gmail.com',  # Must be verified in SendGrid
        to_emails=to_email,
        subject='Your Promo Code!',
        html_content=f'<p>Thank you! Your promo code is <strong>{promo_code}</strong>.</p>'
    )
    try:
        sg = sendgrid.SendGridAPIClient(api_key=settings.SENDGRID_API_KEY)
        response = sg.send(message)
        return response.status_code  # 202 means accepted
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
        return None

âš™ Step 4: Add to settings.py

python
SENDGRID_API_KEY = 'SG.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx'

3. ðŸ“¦ Models: promocode/models.py

python
from django.db import models

class PromoSubmission(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=255)
    email = models.EmailField()
    contact = models.CharField(max_length=20)
    address = models.TextField()
    promo_code = models.CharField(max_length=20)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} - {self.promo_code}"

5. ðŸ‘ï¸ Views: promocode/views.py

python
import qrcode
import io
import random
import string
from django.shortcuts import render, redirect
from django.core.mail import send_mail
from django.http import HttpResponse
from .models import PromoSubmission

def generate_qr(data):
    qr = qrcode.make(data)
    buf = io.BytesIO()
    qr.save(buf, format='PNG')
    return buf.getvalue()

def home(request):
    qr_data = request.build_absolute_uri('/scan/')
    qr_image = generate_qr(qr_data)
    return HttpResponse(qr_image, content_type="image/png")

def generate_promo_code():
    return ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_uppercase + string.digits, k=8))

def scan_qr(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        name = request.POST['name']
        email = request.POST['email']
        contact = request.POST['contact']
        address = request.POST['address']
        promo_code = generate_promo_code()

        # Save to DB
        PromoSubmission.objects.create(
            name=name,
            email=email,
            contact=contact,
            address=address,
            promo_code=promo_code
        )

        # Send Email
        send_mail(
            "Your Promo Code!",
            f"Hi {name}, your unique promo code for 15% off is: {promo_code}",
            "promoqr@example.com",
            [email],
        )

        return render(request, 'promocode/form.html', {'success': True})

    return render(request, 'promocode/form.html')

To separate the styles from the HTML, you'll move the <style> block to a CSS file and link it using Django's {% static %} tag.

âœ… Steps to Split Styling:

1. Create a CSS file

Save the CSS content into a file, for example:

swift

Create the folders if they donâ€™t exist: static/promocode_generatorapp/css/

2. Paste the CSS into promo_form.css

css
/* promo_form.css */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

body {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  background-color: #f4f6f8;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
  min-height: 100vh;
}

.container {
  background-color: #fff;
  padding: 1.5rem;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  width: 100%;
  max-width: 480px;
  margin: 1rem;
}

  text-align: center;

  font-size: 1.4rem;

  display: flex;

textarea,

}

  resize: vertical;
  min-height: 80px;
}

  background-color: #007bff;
  color: white;
  border: none;
  cursor: pointer;

}

button:hover {
  background-color: #0056b3;

.success-message {
  text-align: center;
  margin-bottom: 1rem;
  color: green;

3. Update your HTML file

Replace the <style> tag with a link to the CSS file.

html
{% load static %}
<!DOCTYPE html>

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"/>
  <title>Promo Code Form</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{% static 'promocode_generatorapp/css/promo_form.css' %}">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container">
    <h1>Get Your 15% Promo Code</h1>

    <div class="success-message">
      Your promo code <strong>{{ promo_code }}</strong> has been sent to <strong>{{ email }}</strong>.
    </div>
    {% endif %}

    <form method="POST">
      {% csrf_token %}
      <input type="text" name="name" placeholder="Name" required />
      <input type="email" name="email" placeholder="Email" required />
      <input type="text" name="contact" placeholder="Contact Number" required />
      <textarea name="address" placeholder="Address" required></textarea>
      <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
  </div>
</body>
</html>

ChatGPT said:

If your form styling in the external CSS file isn't reflecting in the webpage, here are the most likely reasons and how to fix them:

âœ… 1. Make Sure Static Files Are Configured Correctly in Django

In settings.py:

python
STATIC_URL = '/static/'

# If you're using development
STATICFILES_DIRS = [BASE_DIR / "static"]

# For production (optional)
# STATIC_ROOT = BASE_DIR / "staticfiles"

âœ… 2. Use {% load static %} in Your Template

You must include {% load static %} at the very top of the HTML file:

django
{% load static %}
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"/>
  <title>Promo Code Form</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{% static 'promocode_generatorapp/css/promo_form.css' %}">
</head>

âœ… 3. Verify Your Folder Structure

Your folder should look like this:

cpp

âœ… 4. During Development: Run Static Files Collection (Optional)

Usually not needed for development, but if you're testing in production or using DEBUG=False, run:

bash

âœ… 5. Hard Refresh the Browser (To Bypass Cache)

Press Ctrl + Shift + R (or Cmd + Shift + R on Mac) to force reload the page.

âœ… 6. Check Dev Tools

Open browser DevTools (F12 or right-click â†’ Inspect) and:

  • Go to Network > CSS tab.

  • Check if promo_form.css is 404 or loading.

  • Make sure its content appears.

To prevent the form from showing again after submission and redirect the user back to the form URL (with the success message and promo details), you should:

âœ… Use redirect with Django's session or query parameters

Hereâ€™s how to do it cleanly:

âœ… Option 1: Use Django session to pass promo_code and email

ðŸ”§ Update your views.py:

python
from django.shortcuts import render, redirect
from django.core.mail import send_mail
from .models import PromoSubmission

def scan_qr(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        name = request.POST['name']
        email = request.POST['email']
        contact = request.POST['contact']
        address = request.POST['address']
        promo_code = generate_promo_code()

        # Save to DB
        PromoSubmission.objects.create(
            name=name,
            email=email,
            contact=contact,
            address=address,
            promo_code=promo_code
        )

        # Send Email
        send_mail(
            "Your Promo Code!",
            f"Hi {name}, your unique promo code for 15% off is: {promo_code}",
            "promoqr@example.com",
            [email],
        )

        # Store success data in session
        request.session['success'] = True
        request.session['email'] = email
        request.session['promo_code'] = promo_code

        return redirect('scan_qr')  # Make sure 'scan_qr' is the name of the URL in urls.py

    success = request.session.pop('success', False)
    email = request.session.pop('email', '')
    promo_code = request.session.pop('promo_code', '')

    return render(request, 'form.html', {
        'success': success,
        'email': email,
        'promo_code': promo_code
    })

ðŸ›  Make sure your urls.py looks like this:

python
from django.urls import path
from . import views

urlpatterns = [
    path('scan/', views.scan_qr, name='scan_qr'),
]

ChatGPT said:

To ensure each email ID can be used only once to generate a QR promo code, follow these steps:

âœ… Step 1: Update Your Model

Assuming your PromoSubmission model looks like this:

python
from django.db import models

class PromoSubmission(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    email = models.EmailField(unique=True)  # âœ… Add unique constraint here
    contact = models.CharField(max_length=15)
    address = models.TextField()
    promo_code = models.CharField(max_length=20)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

If your database already has non-unique emails, youâ€™ll need to clean that data before adding the unique=True constraint.

âœ… Step 2: Update views.py to Check for Existing Email

Modify your scan_qr view like this:

python
from django.db import IntegrityError
from .models import PromoSubmission

def scan_qr(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        name = request.POST['name']
        email = request.POST['email']
        contact = request.POST['contact']
        address = request.POST['address']

        # Check if email already submitted
        existing = PromoSubmission.objects.filter(email=email).first()
        if existing:
            # Show existing promo code
            request.session['submitted'] = True
            request.session['email'] = existing.email
            request.session['promo_code'] = existing.promo_code
            return redirect('scan_qr')

        # Create new entry
        promo_code = generate_promo_code()
        try:
            PromoSubmission.objects.create(
                name=name,
                email=email,
                contact=contact,
                address=address,
                promo_code=promo_code
            )
        except IntegrityError:
            # In case of race condition
            existing = PromoSubmission.objects.get(email=email)
            promo_code = existing.promo_code

        # Send Email
        send_mail(
            "Your Promo Code!",
            f"Hi {name}, your unique promo code for 15% off is: {promo_code}",
            "promoqr@example.com",
            [email],
        )

        # Store success in session
        request.session['submitted'] = True
        request.session['email'] = email
        request.session['promo_code'] = promo_code

        return redirect('scan_qr')

    # GET request
    success = request.session.pop('submitted', False)
    email = request.session.pop('email', '')
    promo_code = request.session.pop('promo_code', '')

    return render(request, 'form.html', {
        'success': success,
        'email': email,
        'promo_code': promo_code,
    })

âœ… Result

  • If an email is reused, it wonâ€™t create a new promo code.

  • Instead, it returns the original promo code and does not send another email.

  • This ensures one QR code per email.

def scan_qr(request):
    if request.method == 'POST':
        name = request.POST['name']
        email = request.POST['email']
        contact = request.POST['contact']
        address = request.POST['address']

        # Check if email already exists
        existing = PromoSubmission.objects.filter(email=email).first()
        if existing:
            promo_code = existing.promo_code
            request.session['email'] = existing.email
            request.session['promo_code'] = promo_code
            request.session['already_exists'] = True
            return redirect('submission_success')

        # Generate new promo code and save
        promo_code = generate_promo_code()
        PromoSubmission.objects.create(
            name=name,
            email=email,
            contact=contact,
            address=address,
            promo_code=promo_code
        )

âœ… 2. Create the submission_success view

python
def submission_success(request):
    email = request.session.get('email')
    promo_code = request.session.get('promo_code')
    already_exists = request.session.get('already_exists', False)

    if not email or not promo_code:
        return redirect('scan_qr')  # fallback if accessed directly

    # Clear session data
    request.session.pop('email', None)
    request.session.pop('promo_code', None)
    request.session.pop('already_exists', None)

    return render(request, 'success.html', {
        'email': email,
        'promo_code': promo_code,
        'already_exists': already_exists,
    })

ChatGPT said:

You're using qrcode.make() to generate a QR code and returning it as an image directly in the home view. This works well for quick testing, but if your goal is to display the QR code inside an HTML page, rather than returning just the raw PNG image, here's how you can improve it:

âœ… Option 1: Embed the QR Code in an HTML Template

Modify your home view to embed the QR code image using a base64 string:

Updated home view:

python
import base64

def home(request):
    qr_data = request.build_absolute_uri('/scan/')
    qr_image = generate_qr(qr_data)
    qr_base64 = base64.b64encode(qr_image).decode('utf-8')
    return render(request, 'home.html', {'qr_base64': qr_base64})

Example home.html template:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}PromoQR Home{% endblock %}

{% block content %}
<div class="container" style="text-align: center; padding: 2rem;">
  <h2>Scan This QR Code</h2>
  <img src="data:image/png;base64,{{ qr_base64 }}" alt="QR Code" />
  <p>Scan the QR to submit your promo details.</p>
</div>
{% endblock %}

âœ… Option 2: Keep returning the raw PNG image

If you want the home view to act as a pure image endpoint, and use <img src="{% url 'home' %}"> inside another template, then keep your current implementation:

python
def home(request):
    qr_data = request.build_absolute_uri('/scan/')
    qr_image = generate_qr(qr_data)
    return HttpResponse(qr_image, content_type="image/png")

Then in another template (like home.html):

html
<img src="{% url 'home' %}" alt="QR Code">

âœ… Summary

  • Use base64 if you want to embed the QR inline in an HTML page.

  • Keep the raw image response if using it as a separate image resource (<img src="/"/>).

You said:
'block' tag with name 'title' appears more than once
ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing:

'block' tag with name 'title' appears more than once

means that in your Django template (likely base.html), the {% block title %} tag is defined more than once. Django does not allow multiple {% block title %} declarations within the same file.

âœ… Solution:

Ensure that base.html contains only one {% block title %} tag. Here's the corrected structure:

âœ… Updated base.html:

html
{% load static %}
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"/>
  <title>{% block title %}Promo Code{% endblock %}</title>
  <!-- All CSS goes here -->
</head>
<body>
  <div class="top-strip">
    <div class="social-icons">
      <!-- Social icons here -->
    </div>
  </div>

  {% block content %}
  {% endblock %}
</body>
</html>

âš ï¸ Common Mistake to Avoid:

html
<title>{% block title %}...</title>   <!-- Good -->
<h1>{% block title %}...</h1>         <!-- âŒ BAD: Don't reuse same block name -->

If you want to customize a heading (like <h1>) inside each page, use a different block name, like {% block heading %}.
